Tigard, Oregon
November 8th 1960
Fellow Worker Thompson!
In regards to Wobbly Folklore, I could perhaps be of some help to you in regards to the song Tie em Up,, now I have sung the song many times in words and music for and to myself and I know the tune and words of the first and part of the second verse, but I am unable to write music and tune in notes, so there is where we neat assistance, I will write the words of the first verse, as I recall it and the refrain and if we get the first verse and refrain in to music all the other verses and refrain are the same tune. I will write the words down to the best of my memory, and you see if you can correct me, if not, we will stick to my words, then I will try to get a party, that can write music and notes and does play Piano! as I live about 10 (over)

miles from Portland Oregon, it would have to be sombody in this Neighborhood, it could are a Finnisch Person, that can write music and you could give my Name and Address in the Industrial Worker, as I am reading it, I am 68 years old and retired and not a card carrying member, I have joined the Wobblies in 1912 i n Minneapolis and was active up to 1950, the last time I heard the Tie em up song sung by a fellow Worker around Christmastime in 1917 in the Wobbly Hall in San Francisco and my melody might be a little out of tune, but that could be adjusted. I have also have heard Joe Hills Workers of the World awaken in 2 different tunes.  
Yours for the O. B. U. 
Alfred Nafken
No. 10855. S. W. Walnut Street
Tigard. Oregon

P.S.
if you have not all the verses, that ago with the song Tie em up, I have another possible chance to trace them. In 1928-1929, I made a trip to my home in Hamburg, Germany and toke 6 Wobbly Song Books along, they where then at that time the latest edition and they most likely had the complete song and possible gave the tune also, but as far as I can remember, it has none of the tune and melody of any other song I know of,  It is in a class by itself! I stayed 11 months in Germany, and had 2 Boys , who wanted to learn "English" and what better Book could I use than the Wobbly Song book, its the tune and the words that sure took them, well I gave each one of the Boys a Wobbly Song Book and kept one for myself as a text book, now this all was way before Hitler toke over, and in the meantime Hamburg was 2/3 destroyed, but as chance would have it my house kept standing, despite the fact that everything for 7 Block square was destroyed
over

when I left Germany in the spring of 1929, I Ieft a lot of books and Literatur behind and it is possible, that a old Wobbly Song book is amongst that. I also found out that one of the Boys I gave a song book at that time survived the war and may still have it. may I suggest, that we ship as many Wobbly Song books by Sailors, to the new created Countries in Africa, mainly to English speaking and former English Colonies as our Wobbly Songs are having the most effect on people who understand and speak english, Now Joe Hills and all the others Wobbly Songs, if translated in to other Languages, even Scandinavian ore German, are not so convincing those written in English, besides in all other languages, the Communist and other Politicians have an awfull gripp on the Working Class and Labor Unions.
Alfred Nafken
No 10855. S.W. Walnut Street
Tigard. Oregon

Anna Smith
P.O. Box 552,
Oakland
Ca. 94604
Fred Thompson
Chicago, Ill. 
Dear F. W., 
Just a few lines - I've owed you more than a few lines for quite a while. 
Misplaced your letter. 
First I read of the loss of your help-mate. I won't extend my sympathy - but say I'm happy she has escaped from latter days of suffering. For you I'm sure you have many happy memories of your life to-gether. 
As to the visit to F.W. in S. F. I went to see them. A pleasant - and some what fruitful unclear. He suggested I go see unclear - "that he is a good unclear" Seems as tho' I have of a remembrance long distance discussion between you and Melvin some years ago. Haven't gotten in touch with the two since nor they with me. 
As to your question I believe it was - Vincent St. John - no, I didn't know him - I've heard of him and read some. 
I don't know any German - studied a little French and Spanish at night school. I should have kept it up.
Hope to buy your First 75 yrs of the I.W.W. one of these days. 
My days with I.W.W. only reaches back to 1937. Y? 31, 32 1929 or 1930 I took part in the Unemployed Movement.

and several related organizations. 
No time not to go into more detail. 
My Dad in 1914 - took us (my 2 brothers and me) to Socialist party crossed out - tickets picnic - in Santa Ana, Southern California - and he voted for Eugene V. Debs - but he and my mother in 1917 (I think it was) voted for Woodrow Wilson for president - because of his promise to keep America out of war. 
My mother with her father in Kansas (he and my grand mother have steaded? 160 acre lot o? acres more) belonged to the Knights of Labor. on the side In 1878 - her family came in covered wagons from Iowa First lived in sod house - burnt buffalo chips water? from river at a distance
I went to see Earl last Sunday. He was sitting on front porch of rest house. He's always seems to be pleased to have visitors. Even in spite of illness - he keeps somewhat the same spirit underneath
-Thats all for now 
Best Wishes
I remain
For O B U?
Anna. 
To Fred Thompson

May 26, 67
Dear Fred, 
In the last few days I have been going thru the little red songbook as well as a microfilm of the IW for 1909-13. I am tempted to write a book on IWW songs but am obligated to finish my coal thesis. 
Meanwhile I prepared 3 checklists for Gibbs: songs, songbooks, ads and articles. Naturally each list can be refined. But I had to mail the sheet? to Gibbs today. The verifax? copies are for your use. 
The unclear material is "frosting" on the cake. 
Cordially, 
Archie

201 West Pennsylvania
Urbana, Illinois
Jan 21,  61
Dear Fred,
Thank you for your welcome letter, the ?  carbon, and the Nafken letter. I respond at once. I did plan to come to Chicago and had indicated to Chuck D. that I would. However, I was quite sick -- flu and fever --and actually lost a week of work.

I had a strong reason to come and see you for there is some good news on my Wob lore project.  I'll try to put it in sequence. About a year ago Phil Taft urged me to visit Dick Brazier in N.Y.C. When Joe Glazer put out his recent book he sent a copy to Brazier and they corresponded. Joe suggested that I see Dick. I went East to Philly for an Am Folklore Society meeting Dec 27-29. From Philly I went up to NY and met Brazier at the Taminent Inst (old Rand School). We chose this site so I could show Dick my microfilm of Neuhaus songbooks. It was the first time he had seen some of his own songs since 1917 when the Feds raided his ? . 

We met on Friday and talked. We returned on Saturday when it was quiet and made a 3 hr tape. I tried to concentrate on the early days in Spokane. Also I tried to explore the problem of

whether Dick or any of the other Wob minstrels and bards were conscious of the folksong concept (as it is used by contemporary academic folklorists).

On New Yrs Eve Dick took me to an IWW party at the home of Becky Dempsey. I met Herbert Mahler, Pete Stone, and others. Dick had given Pete my Neuhaus article. Pete helped me on the songs, He had heard "some 400 cats who had come from the midwest to winter up in Seattle" sing "The Kitten in the Wheat" in 1915. You'll recall that that John Neuhaus had given his source for the "Kitten" as the Literary Digest. It could have been planted against the IWW as a phony. But Pete Stone was quite certain it had been sung and even sang a stanza for me. Naturally I was elated because it was my first evidence that the "Kitten" was actually sung.  

Meanwhile Brazier calmly informed me that "The Kitten" is a direct parody of a well known Cornish poem and song by Robert Stephen Hawker who was also known as "The Vicar of Morwenstow." Morenstow?  The poem is called "The Song of the Western Men" or the "Trewlaney Trelawny? Ballad" since it

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:0

element_texts.text:
3
is built round the refrain: And shall Trewlawney Trelawny? Die? Then 30 000 Cornish boys will know the reason why!
It had been a folk refrain. Hawker turned it into a poem in 1866. It reentered oral tradition. Cousinjack miners sang it: Then 30,000 underground will know the reason why!
At any rate someone who knew the "Trewlawney Ballad" or song, as literature or folksong composed the "Kitten" parody. More on this problem later.
I do not want to bore you with all the details.  But to make a long story short I learned very much from Dick and Pete and plan to correspond with both.
I returned for NY via Akron. There I learned that Joe Glazer had been in Portland at a printing-newspaper strike rally and had had Ralph Chaplin come down from Tacoma to address the rally. Joe got Ralph's talk on tape. If all goes well I'll go to S F on June 5-8 for a library convention. Since I'll have some vacation time coming I'll return to Illinois via Tacoma.  My plan

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:0

element_texts.text:
4
is to visit Chaplin. What is jelling in my mind, Fred, is the necessity to finish Neuhaus' projected book. I have talked to my director, Martin Wagner, who is sympathetic to labor history. I have told him that as soon as I get the library job under control I'll want time off to write a book. So we'll see what happens.
You can see, Fred, why I became sick. I'm running a fair sized library, have two assistants on separate bibliographies, keep students like David Wrone and Marion Ascareli?, and try to pursue my own studies.  It was in NY that I picked up the flu bug that laid me low.
Just a word on Wrone. He has already learned that Carl Person is alive in Chi and a meeting is arranged. My interest here it to push history students into labor history. A fault in our industrial relations?  approach is too much technology and not enuf perspective.
I have raced thru this letter like a house-a-fire. I'll be in Chicago Feb 3-5 with  Louanne for a folk festival at U of Chi. I'll bring her up to visit.
Archie

FW Franklin - The "new" I.W. was widely discussed at our last branch meeting - we do like it + hope the present collective will continue past the May "commitment" - One thing people would like is to have advance notice in the I.W. of the subject matter of upcoming "specials" so we can get articles together - I don't know how much nuke stuff you may include in May's environmental issue - but would an anti-nuke/pro-peace issue be appropriate sometime? For the Work

in pen F. W. Thompson
I recieved your letter concerning a certain Philip Krik in relation to Wobbly history in Detroit.
I don't even know if thereis substantial I.W.W. history in Detroit.
To my knowledge the only wobbly particiation to any significance was the Briggs strike here. The only F.W one that I knof of that was active in that strike was F. W. Frank Cicarelli who has been dead many years.
The only people here who could (possibly) help Krik in any way, you already know if, i.e. Verlani and Lucas both branch secretaries and delegators at one time.
Then, there are the Wayne State archives, which I hardly think would cover all known wobbly history, how I was able to contact Harry Riseman and had an interesting talk.
I was unaware that he was the lawyer who was very instrumental in stopping your deportation altho we didn't finish on that subject.
He, of course immediately recognized your name, in response to my question, does the name of Fred Thompson jar in your memory?

7/8/87
Dear Fellow Worker,
This is in response to Florence Tromater and Jenny Velsek's notice that you are collecting biographical material on Fred Thompson. I am enclosing copies of his correspondence with me - mostly from him to me but a few from myself or my wife to him.
I have put them in chronological order (latest on top) to the best of my ability. Those that are not dated, I have placed according to my best guess as to the time they belong to.
I hope this is useful. Please let me know if you have any questions.
Yours for OBU,
Ed John

Palm, Calif.
Aug. 25, 1968
Dear F.W.T.
More than a month since you mailed that letter dealing with the little red song book so I am late with my response for cause. Been jungling up in the High Sierras for two months during which time I only connected twice with my first class mail and that because of the checks.. Would have stayed away longer but cold wheather chased us southward before the expected time. Ice in the water bucket settled the matter as to stay or not to stay.
I am happy to hear that meaningful improvement will be made in the forthcomming editions of the little red song book. Its about time too, let me tell you.
At this time I have another letter from Dick Brazier saying he was mistaken about being left out in the last printing of the song book. A new york friend of his had told him so in error. Since then he has been supplied with a copy and was happy to find his song in it. All

I sort of liked the little history sketch that D.B. wrote on the little red song book and which Philip Taft saw fit to pick up for Labor History. I don't know if D.B. shares my criticism of the content of the song book. He has not said yet, except to agree with me, that the old English socialist songs are hard to improve on. Songs by F. A. Symonds for example. "These things shall be! A loftier race/Than e'er the world hath known shall rise/With flame of freedom in their souls/And light of knowledge in their eyes." Songs by Morris, Blake, James Russel Lowel, Carpenter, Cooper, Charlotte Perkins Gilman, Joseph Whittaker etc etc.  The inclusion of these authors, or part of them, in your forthcoming editions would still make it a little red  song book though not a little red IWW song book exclusively. As I said in my letter to H. M. E. Seattle much

The correction in the Red Flag is appreciated I mean the line which now reads  -- "Chicago swells its surging "song" should read "surging throng" instead. The fourth verse as rendered in the IWW song book is intirely different in my English I.L.P. song book. There it reads "It well recalls the triumphs past/ It gives the hope of peace at last/ The banner bright, the symbol plain/ Of human right and human gain." There has been a great deal of doctoring up of socialist songs in the past not all of it improving on the authors. Eugene Pottier would not be able to recognise his L'Internationle were he alife today. This brings me to the point that Joe Hills line "the ends the means are justifying" could also be doctored up to conform more closely to our hearts desire. Well, best of luck to (over)

P.S
I like the Front Page of Rebel Worker no. 3
better than The one on Rebel Worker no 2
as its Big Letters in Red and Black
sows up fair for news stands Libraries
and else where.  Its good for the news boys
who sells it also.  Well the nation wide
publicity for the IWW is spreading part of
it good and part of it bad.
Too many writers lie and say the IWW
is dying or is already Dead.  To over
come this IWW Members and Friends must
make a mass distribution of it and [?]
propaganda among the wages slaves
by printed and spoken word coast to
coast.  Organise on the lobs, field
striker, Free speech fight ok.
S Richard Slim. Seattle wash

element_texts.text:
2-15-65

Personal
J.W Rosemont.  The IWW members and
friends out here dont give a damn
whether it even gets off the Subroserve
List or not, they intend to carry on
the struggle for it any way.  From its
very beginning they know only too
well the IWW has always
been on the shit list of the masterclass
and its armed state and
Government.  For years there has been
a few old Marxian Centralizers 
who have wanted to make the IWW
respectable in the eyes of the capitalist
class.  These characters have set around
doing nothing to build it up worrying
only about gettings it off the Subroserve
List for years.  I hope the young Libertarian
IWW's take it own eventually.
yours for a militant youth full
IWW Membership
Guy B Askew (S Richard Slim)
Keep up the Good work for the IWW

Friday 3-5-65

J.W Rosemont - J.W. Oscar Mr Peterson IWW
Branch Secretary appeared on K I R O Radio
Station Television twice yesterday.  When the young
IWW Soap Boxers come to Seattle they should
go to Radio Station and get on The Program
Public Pulse which is on the am
from 8.15 to 9pm every nite but Saturday,
Sunday and other holidays.  They can both
get on the same program at once speak
for the IWW and answer questions from the
Radio audience who phone them in to
the Radio Station from Seattle and
other parts of the North West.
Yours for an anarchist fighting IWW
Membership
Guy B. Askew (S Richard Stein)
Room 25. Freemont Hotel
707- 6th Ave So
Seattle Wash 98104

element_texts.text:
1             3-3-65
It seems to me one issue of the Rebel Worker when
the time comes to put on an organization drive among
the Migratory Farm Workers should be a propaganded
issue devoted to the welfare of the migratory
wage slaves and the families the educational
propaganded of the agracultural workers Industrial
Union of the IWW.  the history of its 1000 man
picket line and many strikes as well as its many
free of speech fights in the harvest fields should be
revived als, especially one like the Minnsot North
Dakota free of speech fight of 1916 when hundreds of
IWW members filled the jails and stockade in 
that city; and won all their demands; to open a
Hall, hold mass meetings on the streets as well as
have IWW news boys on the streets and else
where.  They had to fight the Minot City Bulls,
County Sheriffs and City Fire Dept and beat them
all to a single;  Damn near broke the city of
Mint North Dakota:  They sent in false fire
alarms and cut fire hoses.  They was supported by
The Great Northern Rail Road Shop and Their wives
who marched in a Body to support the IWW
Free of Speech.  Many RR Slaves also carried 
IWW cards also.

IN GOD WE CAN'T TRUST 
Your God? I don't think I could trust Him --
Not from His past record, you see, 
For if He had wives raped in public, (Zech. 14:2)
What might He not do to me? (2 Sam. 16:22)
If He ordered all virgins and babies
Put to death in a killing spree, (Deut. 32:25)
And made poor old Zeke eat cow dung, (Ez. 4:15)
What might He not do to me?

element_texts.text:
ACADEMIE DE MONTPELLIER
Montpellier, le February 17, 1955
COLLEGE LES GARRIGUES
145, avenue du Comte-de-Nice
LA PAILLADE 34100 MONTPELLIER
Telephone 75.20.56
Dear sir,
I am working on a book "The Winning of the War as seen through the Songs of The Time, 1840-1910", And I would like to obtain a xirox of the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, & 4th editions of the IWW's Little Red Songbook "Songs of The Workers, to Fan the Flames of Discontent" published in 1909, 1910, 1920 in Spokane, WA. Could you please suggest possible sources from which I could get photocopies. They have only the 1928 edition in the Library of Congress and and I doubt they store such material in Spokane Public Library, the town being such a conservative place (I know if by experience, I spent two years there)
I read in "Sing Out - the Folksong Magazine" that the 35th edition of the Little Red Song Book was (unknown) Last May - Could you please send me a copy. I have enclosed a check for $3, which should cover the postage by surface mail. (I have already the 45th edition..)
Sincerely, G. Dubois
Guy DUBOIS, Professeur
Fontaine Opaline
134 rue du Curat 
34100 MONTPELLIER

element_texts.text:
21 Dec 81
Dear Fred:
Missed hearing from you but was plagued with medical problems in the family this year. Finally got back on MJ writing but here is the jolly golly season & John, Son #1, home last week for emergency appendectomy so the dust gathers again on typewriter.
I served as consulting historian to Terry Sanders who's working on Mother Jones docs-drama. He & his co-worker wife & their 2 girls & sitter were here for several days. Took Terry and Frieda up cabin & Point Creeks. There were shots in the hills above us which gave them quite a start. Actually it was wild turkey or squirrel season. I haven't seen the script yet but a pro is writing it. All now hangs on funding the film & don't know what will happen with that idiot & his fiscal policies running things from Washington.
Did you make the ILHS mtg in October? I really would have like to have heard a couple of the papers.
Had a postcard from Phillip Foner

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
He's teaching American labor history in China & says he telling Mother Jones story to his students. Says his book Mother Jones Speaks to the Miners will be out in Spring, 1982 by International Publishers.
Ed Steel hitting some interesting stuff for his collection of MJ correspondence. I was interested in the military intelligence reports on MJ during Palmer's campaign & the steel strike.
Went to Morgantown & read Lillian Burgess mss.  Not much there but reports of MJ's visitors interesting.
Don't know what Ed's publishing plans are.
I've been working on proposal for publisher, outline & two chapters since October but I haven't the drive I had before surgery. Guess it takes longer when you get older - except for you.
Hope all is well with you & yours Have a Merry Christmas & Happy New Year
Best Regards 
Lois McL

element_texts.text:
To: Fred Thompson
From: Louis Carrick
Athens -- August 9, 1979
Dear Fred:
I have before me the last letter I received from you. It is dated April 12. I also have note of April 22. Can it be that four months have gone by without exchanging letters? Well, I shall try to make up for this lapse in our correspondence. Your letters mean a great deal to me, Fred. I hope you will find time to answer this one of mine soon.
First, let me thank you for handling my membership effective May 1. I am now a paid-up member in the Public Service IU through December 31, 1979. It is my intention to keep paying my dues to the IWW and to write for the INDUSTRIAL WORKER -- until oxygen no longer gets up to my cerebral cortex. I hope when I turn in my ?   checks, I shall die a member of the IWW in good standing. I shall continue to submit poems and articles for publications under my pen name Louis Burcar. When my name appears in the IW re articles or donations to the Sustaining Fund, it is better that it appear as the pseudonym  by which I became known in the IWW movement than in the form of Louis B. Carrick, the "legal" name under which I now am enrolled in the red membership card I treasure as "Research Biologist," Card No. x 331947, and under which I write checks payable to the organization and also receive the IW and other mail from the General Executive Board. Fellow worker M. Harris now has this double name business straightened out, I believe.
[ In left margin: ] Fred: Please send me by return mail Frank Cederwall's address and telephone number. We are going to ask him to be one of the principal speakers on September 30 at Barnwell ?  civil disobedience -- will pay his expenses to SC.

LC to FT
8/9/79
I am now working as a self exploiter?  as you will note from the enclosed consultant business card. (I resigned from the Federal service July 16, 1979.) I shall send one of these cards to Fellow Worker Hargis so he can transfer me from I.U. 670 to whatever Industrial Union consultants and writers in the field of human ecology may properly belong.
I gain from your note of April 22 that you didn't like my ballad "Harrisburg Blues." But the young scissorbills in the anti-nuke movement down here like it. Lin Mc Nickel Odend'hal, an Athen's folk singer, liked it so much she set it to music and sang it June 2 at a big demonstration at the State Capital steps in Atlanta. (See photos.) Frank Marquart also read the piece as the close of his speech on May Day in Albuquerque. He wrote me it went over big. Lin also got a big hand when she sang H B. We have copyrighted the words and music just so no big-shot could record the piece without clearing with Lin who owns the copyright. Mary scored the piece from LIn's cassette. I shall send you copy of the thing under separate cover. You can try the piece on your own piano -- even you don't like illogical propaganda songs.
The condensation of my "Invocation for May Day" you sent me in your April 12 letter sows excellent test. You used the two stanzas that were most original and forceful. Now

LC to FT  3.
8/9/79
Mary is setting the "Invocation" to music. When she gets the music written, I'll send you a copy so you can try it out. I am submitting "Invocation for May Day" with music for publication in the IW May Day issue of 1980.
Now as to the sonnet you have on file "In Memory of Joe Hill (executed October 19, 1915). I am typing a clan copy and submitting it to the Editorial Collective for publication in a mourning box in the November issue of the IW.
By the way, Frank sent me a Joe Hill petition. Please let me know how the centennial affair is shaping up. I am completely isolated from the movement down here. I carry on as a speaker in the local anti-nuke movement. And, as I believe I showed in my article in the American Nuclear Society which appeared in the July issue of the IW, I am trying to hit with facts at the soft underbelly of the nuclear power industry. I liked the way my piece was featured. I had to call attention through FW Harris, however, that quotation marks in the printed article were improperly placed with relation to periods and commas.
I see from the last bulletin that the IW is in bad straits. I noted you kicked in a $100 for the fund. I shall also contribute when I get some consulting work. Will send you my brochure under separate cover with article which appeared setting forth my position on nuclear power and nuclear warheads in last Thursday's Athens-Banner Herald.
I am doing what I can -- and know you are probably doing more than one man should. Yours L

4814 Kirkwood Rd
Lake Worth, Fla.
May 17, 1969      [33960]
Aissa and Fred Thompson
Dear Friends,
While you were here I promised to mail you a photocopy from the Joe Hill"s "Testament" music. Well finally I did get it done. But like I explained to you that the music that we have is only for mixchorus with finnish words so I'm not sure if this will be any good to you but sill sent it anyway.
Hope that your trip back home went fine. We are also going back North soon although now we have it so nice here that a person hates to leave but as long as we still have our lake cabin in Minnesota we should go there to spent the summer but I do hope that it will be a little warmer than it was last summer.
We both wish you a nice summer.
Olga and Charles Hill

Fred Thompson
Letter to Tom McEnroe   Aug. 13, 1957
" . . . It seems to me that far more of the evils that we face have been fathered by good intentions than by people seeking to do harm or callous about consequences. Maybe what bites me is the large number of instances of the especially mean and malicious things that have been done all for high-sounding moral principles. My favorite text on ethics is Mark Twain's The  Mysterious Stranger."
McEnroe evidently wrote for the IW under the nom de plume Howard Thomas

element_texts.text:
224 Caselli Ave
San Francisco 14, Calif
May 11, 80
Dear Fred,
One of the last things I did before I left school was to address an envelope to you so that I could send you the Boose folktale reference. Here I am 200 miles away and some months later with said envelope on my desk.
Here goes: B. A. BOTKIN, A Treasury of American Anecdotes, N.Y., Random house, 1957. Page 200-201 has Boose's tale, "The Non-Union Calf's Head." Page 301 in a note tells that Botkin collected it August 31, 1950 in Portland, Oregon.
You might enjoy reprinting it in the l. W.  I have already sent to Botkin  the I. W. stories in on Boose's death in 1959. It would be interesting to get a letter or comment on the origin of the tale or any variants.
Now I'll give you a brief report on my activity since we last talked to each other.  From school I returned home for a brief visit in late January. On Feb 12 I returned to Chicago to help launch Glazer's book. I spent a month on the road lecturing on laborlore.  My trip took me from Chicago to Carbondale, Ill., Bloomington, Ind., Columbus, Ohio, Cornell and Rutgers universities, N.Y.C.  and Washington D.C. and home via Detroit for a visit to Solidarity House.

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
2
When I arrived back in San Francisco I was  broke so I returned to the trade. In this period I did no writing. Several weeks ago I took off to look for a library job. I may catch one at San Francisco State College which is close to home. So in the past two weeks I have been trying to write and study a bit. 
Joe Glazer sent me your review of his book. I enjoyed your comment on Casey Jones. In fact I've been doing a bit of reading and speculating as to how the error came about. I'll put all my ideas together into a little article on "the folksong as a historical document." In fact, John Greenway did such an article which I present to you with this letter because of your interest in the subject.
In my own reading on the Harriman Strike I have used 2 books in my library: Carl Person, The Lizard's Trail, Chicago, 1918, and vol 10 of the 1916 US Commission on Industrial Relations, Reports pages 9697-10066. Person deals chiefly with machinists on the Illinois Central. The U.S. Commission Report contains good testimony by John G. Taylor who was the I. A.M. rep. for the California machinists on the S.P.
But what I lack, Fred, is some account in print of the strike in San Pedro in the early months. I assume that the song

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
3
was written by Hill fairly early in the strike. I'd like to find a book, magazine, or previous ?  story on the strike in Pedro when Hill was there. In short, I want some peg upon which to hang his song. If you can help with a reference I may have overlooked please let me know.
By the way, do you know what happened to Person after he wrote the Lizards Tail?  In a sense, Person and Hill had similar reactions to the strike but the song lives on and the book is a forgotten item. I'd like to comment on the contrast.
Now I'll indicate why Glazer's error came about. This is my personal theory. All the people who write about Hill -- pro and con -- seem to be cast under a spell that forgets fact and compounds error.
Chaplin  in Wobbly, pg. 186 places the song on the great strike on the SP in 1910. He is wrong on name of strike and date. Stegner in Preacher and Slave, pps. 13-28 calls it a trainmen SP strike in June, 1910. He repeats Chaplin and involves an operating croft not actually on strike. Stavis ? in Man Who Never Died, pg. 3, corrects date to 1911 and calls it an SP strike. Note all 3 accept fact of strike but title it S.P.

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
4
Now Greenway comes along in A. F. S. P., pg. 186, and says "company words and newspapers show no evidence of a strike" (SP, 1910). Of course  there is no evidence if you look for wrong name and wrong year. In reality, Greenway didn't look hard because Harry McClintock told John it was the Harriman Strike of 1911 which John printed, but didn't follow they to document. At least, McClintock's statement is finally on the record.
Along comes Glazer who combines Stavis and Greenway to make a blooper. There is a further serious error in Stavis when he asserts that Casey Jones was Hills' first known and first printed song. pg. 3. On pg. 8 he calls Preacher & Slave the second of Joe Hills songs. The reverse is true. P. & S. was introduced in Portland in fall of 1910 and printed in summer of 1911, and C J was composed in fall of 1911 and printed in little red songbook in summer of 1912.
I believe that Stavis's error in dating C J helps give it an early [ [in? ]]1910 feeling or at least helps place it before the strike started.
I'll be glad, Fred, to get your comments on my sequence and theory. Now I need some specific help. I'll want a comment on Lizard's Tail in?  Person.

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
5
I'll want a reference to an SP strike story out of Pedro in late 1911 or early 1912.
But most important, have you ever seen the cards on which the song was first printed?  Neuhaus never had one.  I've never seen one reproduced.  I assume the back of the card would have had a message such as "support the strike and possibly a date. Or even a story in the Ind. Worker in late 1911 -- early 1912 that might have said, buy SP song cards. I have the I.W. on microfilm and when I get a chance I'll read these key issues cover to cover. But let me know where to get the original Casey Jones song card. 
There is a final question. Most early "biography" on Hill came from Chaplin. He wrote an early story for the Industrial Pioneer which he later rewrote for the New Masses. Do you have the dates of either of these stories?  I want to read them and compare to his Wobbly account in 1998.
Do you have any memory of anyone writing a "true" history of Hill's Casey Jones? It is devastating to do research and find that it's been done before.

In left margin, addition reads: Ind. Pioneer Nov 1923

24 Palms, Calif
Jan. 2, 1970
Dear f.w. F & A.
Your letter of Dec. 27--69 with ref. to the contents of the Joe Hill song book just issued. Yes sir "nearer my job to Thee" is on page 19 of the above mentioned song book the English version on the next page. The editor says that "it was published in the sixt edition of "The Little Red Songbook." The melody from Lowell Masons "Nearer My God to Thee." The editor name is Enn Kokk  "Coffee An" is on page 32 and titled "Rakna noga" in the Swedish version  It was translated by Jacob Branting and a good job I would say. Musik: E O Excell 1897 ("Count Your Blessings") "Rakna noga" means count carefully.  "Where the Fraser River Flows" which has appeared in some IWW version uncredited to J. H is on page 24. This one is definitely Joe Hillish and Frenchy Moreau, Lone Pine Calif. now dead, did say that Joe Hill certainly was present at the Fraser River job at the time of the strike there. "Down in the Old Dark Mill" and "The Old Toilers Message" are not in this song book and as you imply these may have been written by somebody else.
I don't have a copy of Joyce Kornbluh work on IWW songs. Had it loaned to me by John

Sept. 18, 19979
Chas. H. Kerr Publishing Company
600 W. Jackson Blvd,,
Chicago, Ill.
Attention Beret Rosen
Gentlemen:

  Some months ago I wrote to you requesting return of my manuscript and the $1000.00 given toward publication of same, to which I have received no reply.
  In view of the fact that neither you nor An Illinois Labor History see their way [?] to publish it, I want to make several dozen of mimeograph copies and hereby demand return of my manuscript and the $1000.00 given to [?]
  Should you fail to answer this letter, I will be compelled to take legal action.

Yours [?signature: James S Abrams?]
To Beret Rosen:  I am asking for [?] to pick up my [?} which you failed to repair or sell for me as you suggested.  [signature: ?James S Abrams?]

element_texts.text:
NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY  COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCES  Department of History  Evanston, Illinois 60201  Telephone: (312) 492-3406
29 April 85
Dear Frank Adams,

   I received your understandably angry letter last Friday but never got a copy of Thompson's letter to you.  He called me at one point saying he had some reservations about whether kerr readers -- a notoriously hard-to-define group -- would like the sections on the New Deal and so much on Dombrowski's youth.  I said that I agreed cuts should be made but am very surprised that he wrote saying the book was rejected.   We have a board meeting on 11 May and I will see to it that the issue is resolved, hopefully favorably there by vote.
  Let me reiterate my position and expalin from my viewpoint what has happened to the manuscript.  It sat at Kerr for some months waiting for me to read it upon returning from abroad.  I read it and wrote you to say I liked it and thought it an appropriate Kerr book if there were money.  I also said you might be better advised to try elsewhere.  Your wrote back to say you'd "wait in line". for Kerr to publish.  I pointed out that without cuts and money for printing raised in advance by friends of the book we could not realistically agree to publish it,    ➞

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
at least not for many years.  I was not sure from your letters to me or to Franklin Rosemont whether you thought the money could be raised in advance or only with a tour after publication.  Nor was I sure how a publicity tour would be funded.  Therefore when the book came up at our last meeting and when Fred asked to see it for review I agreed hoping to get suggestions on cutting from the most laconic author I know.   I hoped he'd agreed with my recommendation of it as an appropriate Kerr book but, since we were not straight on financing, I could not press for a vote to publish.

   In the 11 May meeting I will ask for approval to publish pending cuts and raising of the printing costs.  (How much is cut will effect how much needs to be raised).  I think that the meeting should decide in favor given those conditions.  It is possible, if Fred feels strongly, that a third reader would look at it.  I doubt that will happen but if it does I will try to make Franklin Rosemont who liked the ms. based on a brief reading, responsible and get him to act quickly.
  I agree that the situation is a mess and am sorry for the inconvenience.

Sincerely   [signature]  Dave Roidyer

148 Howland Ave., Toronto, Ontario, Canada MSR 385 14/3/78.
Dear Fred Thompson,
I am writing to see if you can help me in some research I'm doing which involves the publishing activities of Charles H. Kerr Books. I recently read your very interesting and stimulating memories of Halifax in 1919 in This Magazine and noticed in the comment by John Bell that like so many you learned your socialism from Charles H. Kerr books and that you are new on the board of that great publishing house.
I've been meaning to write to Kerr Publishing for some time now and after reading your article I thought you would be an excellent person

element_texts.text:
to address my enquiries to.
I am engaged in research on the development of class consciousness among workers in Britain at the beginning of the 20th. In Britain, too, as you well know, many workers learned their socialism from Kerr books. I was wondering if there is a complete history of Kerr books and pamphlets and if the company still has any records of printing runs of the works they published? -- and in particular any records on which books were distributed in Britain and how many copies they sold.
Also is there a list of the subscribers to the Kerr ?  from Britain? I have a copy of the 1913 Kerr edition of Arthur Lewis' "An introduction to Sociology" and at the back of that os "list of advance subscribers" but they all seem to be U. S. subscribers. Is there also a list of UK subscribers surviving somewhere?
I'm all obviously interested in the general

element_texts.text:
2.
development of the company and particularly how it built up its distribution network in Britain.  I know Kerr books were distributed by the CP in Britain but before that I'm not too sure. Are there any general accounts of the history of the Company that you know of?
I'll call a halt now as I've pestered you with enough questions for one short letter! If the company does have records which would help to answer some of my questions I would be most grateful if I could gain permission to examine them.   In any event I wish you well and look forward to hearing from you. Thanks.
Sincerely,
Bob Jones
(R.W. Jones).

6 Lilian ST, Bradford, BD4 9LP England. 15/Jan. '81.
Dear Fred,
Many thanks for the letter you sent way back in March. Since then I've moved back from Toronto to England for a while and I thought I would wait until finding some more Kerr information before writing again.
As you can see for from the enclosed copy I've come across a Kerr share certificate which I hope is of some interest. It was held by Harry Brownjohn and is now in the possession of Eddie Crow who, I think, knew Harry well.  Harry (like Eddie) was an engineering worker & member of the SDF and ILP becoming a foundation member of the CP. He was also, not surprisingly, a member of the Plebs League and a class tutor.
written at top: Kerr Histor

It is surprising that Kerr (and other American material especially Vanguard Press & SLP pamphlets) were so important here and it would be very interesting to speculate why this was so. I suppose the simple reason was that there was no major socialist publishing co. here publishing anything on any sizeable scale.   Most socialist literature published here was put out by strictly commercial companies although a number sympathetic, to some degree, to the labor movement.  I'm thinking of Swan Sonenschein, T Fisher Unwin G. Allen & Unwin in particular. element_texts.text:
Feb. 1980
To whom it may concern --
On May 1st, 1986, it will be 100 years since the "Haymarket Massacre" in Chicago, when the budding labor movement was struggling to make the 8-hr. day standard throughout the nation. One of their songs went,
"Eight hours we'd have for sleeping
Eight hours we'd have for play
Eight hours we'd have for working
In Free Americay"
May 1st became an international labor holiday, but in recent decades, especially in the USA, each left-wing sect has held its separate observance, more of a memorial than a celebration, and established unions tended to ignore the date completely, or join the "Loyalty Parades" sponsored by the American Legion.
I think that musicians and song-leaders are needed now to take the initiative, and project a little unity into the situation. One week (or one month?) before May day, in each city and town of the country, we should invite one and all to an evening which could be advertised as "A  May Day Centennial Rehearsal Warm-up." A number of different singers and song leaders could be invited, and a few basic rules agreed upon: 
1. No speeches, except a 30-second introduction

element_texts.text:
p.2
to a song, briefly establishing the singer's point of view, or organizational base.
2. A balance between new and old songs. A pure historical survey, with all songs in chronological order, might get pretty boring. So each singer might search for contrasts, and agree to sing at least one old and one newer song.
3. Face up to disagreements, and sing songs that don't always agree with each other. This will add a good dramatic tension to the evening, and even some humor.
4. A printed songbook should be available so everyone present could go back (to their local union?) and lead a few songs somewhere on May 1st
Who knows, if such programs are put on for six years in a row, perhaps in 1986 there might even be some united celebrations of May Day.
In 1980, our songfests will be pitifully small because of lack of time and money for preparation, but I mail these pages to friends in many places, hoping for letters in response. Here I jot down, off the cuff, names of singers and songs I'd try to get for such a gathering, if I

element_texts.text:
3/27/87
Friend,
I heard a few days ago that Fred died a couple of weeks ago. I was sorry to hear that, since I was hoping to see him when I come out  for the Convention in September. (I was last out there in Sept 84: I stayed at your place, and Fred and I went to the bus station at about 5 AM to look for someone we thought might be coming in from Missouri.)
I've been going to Physical Therapy school for the last two years, which is why I've had very little time for IWW activities. I've had the chance to work with patients who have lost or are losing muscular control of their bodies (specifically MS, & stroke patients as well as quadriplegics). I know the support and caring of others make a big difference in those times, and I am glad Fred had this support.
As I think about Fred, there are two factors of his life which I especially am glad for. First, he lived his life for what he believed in, and he did it almost right to the end. He did not take the selfish or safe path, but rather he was willing to risk comfort, treasure, and safety for his ideals and as an expression of love for others, without any hope or intention of personal gain. There are all to few people like that, and they deserve the highest respect; Fred certainly has my respect & deepest appreciation.
Second, I feel Fred was very lucky to have a loyal and loving companion like yourself in the latter part of his life.

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:2

element_texts.text:
Many seek this kind  of loving companionship and few are lucky enough to find it or to work for it. I am sure you each enhanced each others life substantially -- I am glad you were there for each other.
I feel what is important about life is not how long we live, but how we live our lives.  Fred decided to give himself for what he believed in, and I remember him in that image, not the way he was at the end of this phase of his existence. We have all been blessed to be able to share with him.
Peace to you,
Tom Hill
x331984
Delegate 86-22
P.S. One of the more important things I have learned in my life is to be sure I am seeing people & events from an honest perspective. I see life as one phase of existence -- death is passage to a higher plane of existence. Richard Bach said it in a much more poetic way in his book Illusions:
"What the caterpillar calls
the end of the world, the
master calls a butterfly."

element_texts.text:
January 5, 1988
Dear Danny:

   Here is the article I promised hoping it is not too long.   Paul had a lot to say in his own modest way and I believe it deserves to be read treading his fascinating lfe through four unions.
  I have inserted comments here and there solely for clarity and rearranged some of the speech into chronoligical order.   All the quotes are his simple but eloquent with the use of certain I.W.W. words and phrases lost in the continuance of time.   To be sure the message is as important today as it was in his era.

Respectfully, [signature] Art Almeida
Dear Fred

  Enclosed please find an article/obituary for former I.W.W. organizer and class war prisoner Paul Ware.  he died 18 De. 1987  Thought you might want to run some info on him  By the way when I corresponded with Fred Thompson it came out that he knew Paul at Quentin   In factI got a copy of the letter he wrote to Paul less than two years ago.  Small world.   Also I am sending you two Xerox copies of Paul & fellow workers & the list of class-war roster at S.Q.  Note Freds name.  I have misplaced the list that included Paul name.  [?] [signature] Art Almeida

[additional comment in red ink]  This article was sent to the LWU newspaper the Dispatcher

Sept 20
IWW Folks;
Hello.  Have a copy of our Inter-Prison Newspaper.  We hope to cover your prison union representation in Ohio in the next issue.  The idea set discussed here.

  Sorry about the quality, we hve to use a lot of caron paper as our printing medium here.  This is hot off the "press".  You might direct the thing by C. C. Redcloud.
  Got plenty to mail tonight

P; Oppresso Libre
[Signature}
Jeffrey Thompson #6298B
